full_threads.body:

If it is to send the original email blast to the rest of the database then am guessing I will need to 'add' these email addresses to a new segment list so that those who received it the first time won't receive it again? Or was the purpose of this for future email blasts specific to Luke?



Thanks!






Warm regards,

Hi Ben, Sure, this happens sometimes for a variety of factors. To help bring some clarity, here as some of the more common reasons:
  • They may be a 'catch all' account, e.g. info@, team@ etc. MailChimp (and other providers) tend to advise against having too many of these as they tend to go to a group of recipients. If any one of those recipients marks an email as spam, you can no longer send to any of them. If then in a blast a large amount of people unsubscribe/mark as spam, MailChimps email servers can be blocked. This then means that if that email address is on a list of an entirely different company, MailChimps emails to that domain won't be accepted. So they are trying to protect themselves and in turn their customers.
  • They may be suspicious of the size of your list. If you show up one day with xxx thousand of email addresses, this is an indicator to MailChimp that you may have obtained these either by scraping websites, buying email addresses, hacking etc. So to be safe, they say no and ask you to get these people to sign up in a more legitimate way such as online subscription form.
  • They may have seen these users before (and had a bad experience). If for example Luke was at previous company that was heavy handed with the email campaigns and had high opt out or poor delivery rates, then MailChimp would put this email address through its past experience and be weary to add them to your list. Once again to protect them and in turn you.
These are just a few of the main reasons I have come across. So what can you do? The best way is to add them over time from the website subscribe form. Your team can do this or Luke can reach out or add something to his email signature encouraging his contacts to take this action. The key here is to have it happen over a period of time making it more plausible and therefore likely to slip in under the radar. It's painful, but the most full proof way. The benefit of this also is that the contacts being added will be engaged, relevant and have a higher yield. Hope that helps to clarify? It's no silver bullet, but a solution nonetheless. Let me know if I can help any further with this.

Hi Ben, 

I have imported and as suspected it failed, see attached screen shot. 

When MailChimp imports, they run the email addresses through a series of filters to determine things like, if the email address is still active, if they have previously emailed to it and it's bounced, if it's a 'catch all' account etc. 

The reality is that even if you were able to email to these addresses (and lower grades) the likely-hood of a positive result would be slim to none (accordingly to MailChimp and datavalidation.com). It's generally recommended to exclude them as it can affect your sending reputation with companies like MailChimp and certainly will skew your results if there are around 10k+ of 'dud' emails in your campaigns, if that makes sense?

Sorry we can't do much else in this case.

action.text: Heath Maguire assigned to Heath Maguire

full_threads.body:
Hi Ben, 

Ok so I have been working on this. I did the datavalidation.com review and tried to upload all 'legit' emails with varying grades (A, B and D). There was around 7k of them. 

MailChimp kept knocking them back, however, when I only upload the A grades they are being accepted. So the only useable emails out of the initial 12k list is 1,581. 

They are in a list called New Contacts. I would recommend leaving them in an isolated list, doing your blast and 'seeing what happens'. Reason I recommend this is if MailChimp blocks the list, only this list will be affected and not your larger 8k and 5k+ lists. Once we know they are being accepted, I can merge them into the larger list safely. Does that suit you? Feel free to give me a buzz if the above is not making sense?

Yes proceed with the $60 option Heath.


Ben Grace

Hi Ben, 

I uploaded the list and MailChimp blocked it - I had a feeling this would happen! See attached. 

So I have run it through datavalidation.com and am going to try and bring it in 'via the back door' - I remember we did this for you back in the Unispec days. It has found that out of the 12k contacts, only 8k have email addresses and they recommend that only 20% of these are actually valid, see attached. We will need to pay approx $60USD to get them to clean the list and then import it into MailChimp. Are you ok for me to proceed with this? 

Your other option would be to send directly from Luke's email account, but I strongly advise against this as the acoufelt.com domain (and all of your emails) could end up on some black lists. They have got you between a rock and hard place unfortunately. Let me know how you would like to proceed?

I know!






Warm regards,



Ben Grace
Co-Founder
t +61 1800.62.64.62 m +61 407.075.840Level 4 108 King William Street Adelaide SA 5000acoufelt.com
